Methods

Zhuoran (Angela) Yu

2025-10-24

Methods.Rmd

Definition of Inverse Set and Introduction of the Estimation Method

The identification of domain sets whose outcomes belong to predefined subsets can address fundamental risk assessment challenges in climatology and medicine. A motivating example involves estimating geographical regions where average difference between summer and winter temperatures exceeds a certain benchmark, which helps policymakers focus on specific areas that are at higher risk for effects of climate change.

Mathematically, the target region corresponding to the inverse image of U‚äÇ‚ÑùU \subset \mathbb{R} under an unknown function Œº:ùíÆ‚Üí‚Ñù\mu: \mathcal{S} \to \mathbb{R}, can be defined as Œº‚àí1(U)={s‚ààS:Œº(s)‚ààU} \mu^{-1}(U) = \{s \in S: \mu(s) \in U\} , with UU a pre-specified subset of a real line ‚Ñù\mathbb{R} (e.g., [c,‚àû)[c, \infty)).

A point estimator for the inverse set can be constructed as ŒºÃÇn‚àí1(U)\hat{\mu}_n^{-1}(U), where ŒºÃÇn\hat{\mu}_n is an empirical estimator of Œº\mu based on nn observations. To quantify the spatial uncertainty of this estimate, Sommerfeld et al. (2018) introduced the Coverage Probability Excursion (CoPE) sets, defined as: CRin(U)‚äÜŒº‚àí1(U)‚äÜCRout(U) \text{CR}_{\text{in}}(U) \subseteq \mu^{-1}(U) \subseteq \text{CR}_{\text{out}}(U) which satisfy: ‚Ñô(CRin(U)‚äÜŒº‚àí1(U)‚äÜCRout(U))‚â•1‚àíŒ± \mathbb{P}\left(\text{CR}_{\text{in}}(U) \subseteq \mu^{-1}(U) \subseteq \text{CR}_{\text{out}}(U)\right) \geq 1 - \alpha for a pre-specified confidence level 1‚àíŒ±1-\alpha (e.g., Œ±=0.05\alpha = 0.05).

Existing approaches require restrictive assumptions, including domain density of SS in RR, continuity of ŒºÃÇn\hat{\mu}_n and Œº\mu near thresholds, and large-sample guarantees, which limit the applicability. Besides, the estimation and coverage depend on setting a fixed threshold level, which is difficult to determine.

Ren et al. (2024) proposed a framework that generalizes the estimation of such inverse sets to dense and non-dense domains with protection against inflated Type I error, and constructs multiple upper, lower or interval confidence regions of Œº‚àí1(U)\mu^{-1}(U) over arbitrary chosen thresholds. The coverage probability is achieved non-asymptotically and simultaneously through inverting simultaneous confidence intervals. For instance, suppose we are interested in inverse regions Œº‚àí1([c,‚àû))\mu^{-1}([c,\infty)) for a single value cc, the inverse confidence regions are constructed by inverting simultaneous confidence intervals (SCIs). Given SCI bounds BÃÇl(ùê¨)\hat{B}_{l}(\boldsymbol{s}) and BÃÇu(ùê¨)\hat{B}_{u}(\boldsymbol{s}) satisfying:

‚Ñô(‚àÄùê¨‚ààùíÆ:BÃÇl(ùê¨)‚â§Œº(ùê¨)‚â§BÃÇu(ùê¨))=1‚àíŒ± \mathbb{P}\left(\forall\boldsymbol{s}\in\mathcal{S}: \hat{B}_{l}(\boldsymbol{s}) \leq \mu(\boldsymbol{s}) \leq \hat{B}_{u}(\boldsymbol{s})\right) = 1-\alpha

The inner and outer confidence regions (CRs) for the inverse upper excursion set Œº‚àí1[c,‚àû)\mu^{-1}[c, \infty) are defined as:
CRin[c,‚àû):=BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1[c,‚àû) \text{CR}_{\text{in}}[c, \infty) := \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}[c, \infty)

CRout[c,‚àû):=BÃÇu‚àí1[c,‚àû) \text{CR}_{\text{out}}[c,\infty) := \hat{B}_u^{-1}[c, \infty)

The outer and inner confidence regions for the inverse lower excursion set Œº‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,c]\mu^{-1}\left(-\infty, c\right] are defined as:

CRin(‚àí‚àû,c]:=BÃÇu‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,c]=(BÃÇu‚àí1[c,+‚àû))‚àÅ \text{CR}_{\text{in}}\left(-\infty, c\right] := \hat{B}_u^{-1}\left(-\infty, c\right] = \left( \hat{B}_u^{-1}\left[c, +\infty\right) \right)^{\complement} CRout(‚àí‚àû,c]:=BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,c]=(BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1[c,+‚àû))‚àÅ \text{CR}_{\text{out}}\left(-\infty, c\right] := \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}\left(-\infty, c\right] = \left( \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}\left[c, +\infty\right) \right)^{\complement}

The inner and outer CRs for the inverse interval set Œº‚àí1[a,b]\mu^{-1}[a, b] are defined as:

CRin[a,b]:=BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1[a,‚àû)‚à©BÃÇu‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,b] \text{CR}_{\text{in}}[a, b] := \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}[a, \infty) \cap \hat{B}_u^{-1}(-\infty, b]

CRout[a,b]:=BÃÇu‚àí1[a,‚àû)‚à©BÃÇ‚Ñì‚àí1(‚àí‚àû,b] \text{CR}_{\text{out}}[a, b] := \hat{B}_u^{-1}[a, \infty) \cap \hat{B}_\ell^{-1}(-\infty, b]

Linear Function-on-Scalar Regression (FoSR)

A simple example for function-on-scalar regression model is

Yi(t)=Œ≤0(t)+Œ≤1(t)Xi1+bi(t)+œµi(t), Y_i(t) = \beta_0(t) + \beta_1(t) X_{i1} + b_i(t) + \epsilon_i(t),

where:

  • Yi(t)Y_i(t) is a functional outcome
  • Xi1X_{i1} is a scalar covariate
  • Each Œ≤j(t)\beta_j(t) is a coefficient function
  • bi(t)b_i(t) is a subject-specific functional random effect. This captures correlation within subjects over time that is not captured by the mean. This term is not always included in FoSR models, but it‚Äôs generally a good idea because it gives better inference
  • œµi(t)\epsilon_i(t) are normally distributed iid errors

Here, the same bases are used for Œ≤1(t)\beta_1(t) and Œ≤2(t)\beta_2(t).

Accounting for Error Correlation

The fitted GAM model above didn‚Äôt take the correlation of residuals into account. Here, we combined random effects and FPCA into the GAM model to resolve this.

Modeling residuals with FPCA and gam

First, fit the mean model:

Yi(t)=Œ≤0(t)+Œ≤1(t)Xi1+ei(t), Y_i(t) = \beta_0(t) + \beta_1(t) X_{i1} + e_i(t),

Estimate the FPCA for GAMM FPCA model

After obtaining residuals from the mean model, FPCA models the residuals using equation ei(s)=bi(s)+œµi(s)e_i(s) = b_i(s) + \epsilon_i(s), where bi(s)b_i(s) follows a mean zero Gaussian Process (GP) with covariance function Œ£\Sigma, and œµi(s)\epsilon_i(s) are independent N(0,œÉe2)N(0, \sigma_e^2) random errors.

Assuming that œïk(‚ãÖ)\phi_k(\cdot) are the eigenfunctions of the covariance operator KXK_X of bi(‚ãÖ)b_i(\cdot), one can express:

bi(t)=‚àëk=1‚àûŒæikœïk(t) b_i(t) = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \xi_{ik} \phi_k(t)

The GAMM-FPCA model will be :

Yi(t)=Œ≤0(t)+Œ≤1(t)Xi1+‚àëk=1KŒæikœïk(t)+œµi(t), Y_i(t) = \beta_0(t) + \beta_1(t) X_{i1} + \sum_{k=1}^{K} \xi_{ik} \phi_k(t) + \epsilon_i(t),

Construction of Simultaneous Confidence Bands for Functional Regression Model

We consider simultaneous confidence bands (SCBs) for a target function Œ∑(‚ãÖ)\eta(\cdot) on a grid ùíÆ\mathcal{S}. For example, Œ∑(‚ãÖ)\eta(\cdot) could be Yi(t)Y_i(t) or Œ≤1(t)\beta_1(t). Given an estimator Œ∑ÃÇN(s)\hat{\eta}_N(s) with pointwise standard error Œ∂ÃÇN(s)\hat{\zeta}_N(s) and a normalizing factor œÑN\tau_N, we can define the simultaneous confidence band for Œ∑(‚ãÖ)\eta(\cdot) as: SCB(s;qŒ±,N)=[Œ∑ÃÇN(s)‚àíqŒ±,NŒ∂ÃÇN(s)œÑN,Œ∑ÃÇN(s)+qŒ±,NŒ∂ÃÇN(s)œÑN]. \mathrm{SCB}(s;q_{\alpha,N}) = \Big[\, \hat{\eta}_N(s) - q_{\alpha,N}\tfrac{\hat{\zeta}_N(s)}{\tau_N},\; \hat{\eta}_N(s) + q_{\alpha,N}\tfrac{\hat{\zeta}_N(s)}{\tau_N} \Big]. And we can verify that these bands achieve (1‚àíŒ±)(1-\alpha) simultaneous coverage by ‚Ñô(‚àÄs‚ààùíÆ:Œ∑(s)‚ààSCB(s;qŒ±,N))=1‚àíŒ±, \mathbb{P}\!\left(\forall s\in\mathcal{S}:\; \eta(s)\in \mathrm{SCB}(s;q_{\alpha,N})\right)=1-\alpha, whenever the critical value qŒ±,Nq_{\alpha,N} satisfies ‚Ñô(maxs‚ààùíÆœÑNŒ∑ÃÇN(s)‚àíŒ∑(s)Œ∂ÃÇN(s)>qŒ±,N)=Œ±. \mathbb{P}\!\left(\max_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\, \tau_N\, \frac{\hat{\eta}_N(s)-\eta(s)}{\hat{\zeta}_N(s)} \;>\; q_{\alpha,N}\right)=\alpha.

The qŒ±,Nq_{\alpha,N} is unknown in practice. In SCoRES, we implement two approaches for estimating the qŒ±,Nq_{\alpha,N} for functional parameter functions in FoSR model: the Correlation and Multiplicity-Adjusted (CMA) bands (Crainiceanu et al. (2024)) based on parameter simulations, and a multiplier bootstrap procedure (Telschow & Schwartzman (2022)). We detail the CMA procedure below:

Correlation and Multiplicity Adjusted (CMA) Confidence Bands Based on Parameter Simulations

  1. Simulate model parameters ùõÉ1,‚Ä¶,ùõÉB‚àºi.i.d.ùí©(ùõÉÃÇ,VÃÇùõÉ)\boldsymbol{\beta}_1, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\beta}_B \overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim} \mathcal{N}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{V}_{\boldsymbol{\beta}}), where (ùõÉÃÇ,VÃÇùõÉ)(\hat{\boldsymbol{\beta}}, \hat{V}_{\boldsymbol{\beta}}) are estimated from a fitted FoSR model.

  2. For each b=1,‚Ä¶,Bb=1,\ldots,B, compute ùêób=ùêÅ(Œ≤b‚àíŒ≤ÃÇ)ùêÉf, \mathbf{X}_b \;=\; \frac{\mathbf{B}(\beta_b - \hat{\beta})}{\mathbf{D}_f}, where the division is element-wise and ùêÅ\mathbf{B} maps parameters to functional effects.

  3. Define db=max(|ùêób|),b=1,‚Ä¶,B, d_b \;=\; \max\!\big(|\mathbf{X}_b|\big), \quad b=1,\ldots,B, where the absolute value is taken element-wise.

  4. Estimate qŒ±,Nq_{\alpha,N} as the (1‚àíŒ±)‚ãÖ100%(1 - \alpha) \cdot 100\% quantile of {d1,‚Ä¶,dB}\{d_1,\ldots,d_B\}.

Multiplier-t Bootstrap Procedure for Constructing Confidence Bands

The second is the multiplier-t bootstrap procedure for constructing confidence bands. A full introduction to the method can be found in previous work from .

  1. Compute residuals R1N,‚Ä¶,RNNR_1^N, \ldots, R_N^N, where RnN=NN‚àí1(Yn‚àíŒºÃÇN)R_n^N = \sqrt{\frac{N}{N - 1}} \left( Y_n - \hat{\mu}_N \right), and multipliers g1,‚Ä¶,gN‚àºi.i.d.gg_1, \ldots, g_N \overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim} g with ùîº[g]=0\mathbb{E}[g] = 0 and var[g]=1\mathrm{var}[g] = 1, where ŒºÃÇN\hat{\mu}_N is the fitted mean value from a FoSR model.

  2. Estimate œµÃÇN*(s)\hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s) from g1Y1(s),‚Ä¶,gNYN(s)g_1 Y_1(s), \ldots, g_N Y_N(s).

  3. Compute T*(s)=1N‚àën=1NgnRnN(s)œµÃÇN*(s) T^*(s) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} \sum_{n=1}^N g_n \frac{R_n^N(s)}{\hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s)}

  4. Repeat steps 1 to 3 many times. Take the (1‚àíŒ±)‚ãÖ100%(1 - \alpha) \cdot 100\% quantile of ‚Ñí*\mathcal{L}^* to estimate qŒ±,Nq_{\alpha, N}.

At step 2, we allow three choices for the multiplier distribution gig_i, each with mean zero and unit variance:

  1. rademacher: gi‚àà{‚àí1,+1}g_i \in \{-1,+1\} with equal probability;

  2. gaussian: gi‚àºùí©(0,1)g_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1);

  3. mammen: a two‚Äìpoint distribution with mean 00 and variance 11 from .

Unless stated otherwise, we use the rademacher multipliers.

At step 3, we consider two alternatives for the pointwise standard errors œµÃÇN*(sj)\hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s_j):

  1. regular, œµÃÇN*(sj)=1n‚àëi=1n(Yi(sj)‚àíŒ≤ÃÇ(sj))2/(n‚àí1); \hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s_j) = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n\big(Y_i(s_j)-\hat{\beta}(s_j)\big)^2/(n-1)}\,;

  2. t, œµÃÇN*(sj)=NN‚àí1|ùîºb[Yb(sj)2]‚àí(ùîºb[Yb(sj)])2|, \hat{\epsilon}_N^*(s_j) = \sqrt{\frac{N}{N-1}\,\Big|\mathbb{E}_b\!\big[Y^{b}(s_j)^2\big] - \big(\mathbb{E}_b[Y^{b}(s_j)]\big)^2\Big|}, where expectations are taken over bootstrap replicates and Yb(sj)Y^{b}(s_j) denotes the perturbed sample at iteration bb. The absolute value improves numerical stability when subtracting nearly equal quantities.

Unless noted otherwise, we report results using the t estimator.

Construction of Simultaneous Confidence Bands for Linear/Logistic Regression Model

We next describe the bootstrap algorithm used to construct simultaneous confidence intervals (SCIs) for the mean outcome of regression on a fixed test design matrix. We also use the same procedures for the construction of SCIs for the regression coefficients. For details of this algorithm, please refer to .

Suppose we have training data outcome yy, design matrix XX, and a fixed test design matrix XÃÉ\tilde{X}. Let f(Œ≤,X)f(\beta, X) denote the fitted regression function. The algorithm proceeds as follows.

First, we estimate Œ≤ÃÇ\hat{\beta} on the training data (y,X)(y, X) using least squares. Then we compute the estimated mean outcome on the test design matrix EÃÇ(yÃÉ):=f(Œ≤ÃÇ,XÃÉ)\hat{E}(\tilde{y}) := f(\hat{\beta}, \tilde{X}), together with its standard deviation œÉÃÇ\hat{\sigma}.

For bootstrap samples b=1,‚Ä¶,Lb=1,\ldots,L, repeat:

  1. Resample (yb,Xb)(y_b, X_b) with replacement from the training data.

  2. Fit the model on the resampled data to obtain Œ≤ÃÇb\hat{\beta}_b.

  3. Compute the estimated mean EÃÇ(yÃÉb):=f(Œ≤ÃÇb,XÃÉ)\hat{E}(\tilde{y}_b):=f(\hat{\beta}_b, \tilde{X}) and its pointwise standard deviation œÉÃÇb\hat{\sigma}_b.

  4. Calculate the standardized absolute residuals on the test design grid, rb=|EÃÇ(yÃÉb)‚àíEÃÇ(yÃÉ)|œÉÃÇb. r_b = \frac{\big| \hat{E}(\tilde{y}_b) - \hat{E}(\tilde{y}) \big|}{\hat{\sigma}_b}.

  5. Record the maximum value of rbr_b as rbmaxr^{\max}_b.

After LL bootstrap iterations, take the (1‚àíŒ±)(1-\alpha) quantile of the empirical distribution of {rbmax}b=1L\{r^{\max}_b\}_{b=1}^L as the threshold aa. The SCI on the test design matrix is then given by (EÃÇ(yÃÉ)‚àía√óœÉÃÇ,EÃÇ(yÃÉ)+a√óœÉÃÇ). \Big( \hat{E}(\tilde{y}) - a \times \hat{\sigma}, \;\; \hat{E}(\tilde{y}) + a \times \hat{\sigma} \Big). For logistic regression, the SCI is further transformed back to the data scale using the link function.

Construction of SCB for Spatial Generalized Least Square Model

We also provide tools in SCoRES for estimating SCB of geographic data, however, their use is currently limited to the spatial generalized least squares model.

Let the spatial domain be sampled on spots s‚ààùíÆs\in\mathcal S with coordinates s=(xs,ys)s=(x_s,y_s). At each spot ss, we observe nn outcomes ùê≥s‚àà‚Ñùn\mathbf z_s\in\mathbb R^{n} with design matrix ùêó‚àà‚Ñùn√óp\mathbf X\in\mathbb R^{n\times p}. We fit a spot-specific generalized least squares (GLS) model

ùê≥s=ùêóùõÉ(s)+ùõÜs,ùõÜs‚àºùí©(ùüé,ùêïs), \mathbf z_s=\mathbf X\boldsymbol\beta(s)+\boldsymbol\varepsilon_s,\qquad \boldsymbol\varepsilon_s\sim \mathcal N\!\left(\mathbf 0,\ \mathbf V_s\right),

where the variance-covariance matrix within the spot encodes the prespecified correlation structure ùêïs\mathbf V_s.

SCoRES allows users to directly input the matrix ùêïs\mathbf V_s for each spot ss, or specify the correlation structure ùêë\mathbf R.

Assume we are interested in the linear functional Œ∑(s)=ùê∞‚ä§ùõÉ(s)\eta(s)=\mathbf w^\top \boldsymbol\beta(s), with ùê∞\mathbf w as a weight vector for the specific linear combination. The pointwise estimated standard error is

Œ∂ÃÇ(s)=ùê∞‚ä§Var(Œ≤(s))ùê∞. \widehat{\zeta}(s)=\sqrt{\mathbf w^\top \mathrm{Var}(\beta(s))\, \mathbf w}.

To quantify uncertainty uniformly across spots, we construct a simultaneous confidence band (SCB) for Œ∑(‚ãÖ)\eta(\cdot) on the grid ùíÆ\mathcal S:

SCB(s;qŒ±)=[Œ∑ÃÇ(s)‚àíqŒ±Œ∂ÃÇ(s),Œ∑ÃÇ(s)+qŒ±Œ∂ÃÇ(s)],s‚ààùíÆ, \mathrm{SCB}(s;\,q_\alpha)=\Big[\ \widehat{\eta}(s)-q_\alpha\,\widehat{\zeta}(s),\ \ \widehat{\eta}(s)+q_\alpha\,\widehat{\zeta}(s)\ \Big],\qquad s\in\mathcal S,

where qŒ±q_\alpha satisfies

‚Ñô(maxs‚ààùíÆ|Œ∑ÃÇ(s)‚àíŒ∑(s)|Œ∂ÃÇ(s)‚â§qŒ±)=1‚àíŒ±. \mathbb P\!\left(\max_{s\in\mathcal S}\frac{|\widehat{\eta}(s)-\eta(s)|}{\widehat{\zeta}(s)} \le q_\alpha\right)= 1-\alpha.

We estimate qŒ±q_\alpha by multiplier-tt bootstrap method introduced before.

Crainiceanu, C. M., Goldsmith, J., Leroux, A., & Cui, E. (2024). Functional data analysis with r. Chapman; Hall/CRC.
Ren, J., Telschow, F. J. E., & Schwartzman, A. (2024). Inverse set estimation and inversion of simultaneous confidence intervals. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society Series C: Applied Statistics, 73(4), 1082‚Äì1109. https://doi.org/10.1093/jrsssc/qlae027
Sommerfeld, M., Sain, S., & Schwartzman, A. (2018). Confidence regions for spatial excursion sets from repeated random field observations, with an application to climate. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 113(523), 1327‚Äì1340. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2017.1341838
Telschow, F. J. E., & Schwartzman, A. (2022). Simultaneous confidence bands for functional data using the gaussian kinematic formula. Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, 216, 70‚Äì94. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jspi.2021.05.008
